snippet: The anxiety disorder affects roughly one in 140 children. Researchers are taking a different tack in treating it: intensive immersion programs.
abstract: Researchers studying selective mutism in children, social anxiety disorder marked by fear of speaking in social situations, are testing weeklong immersion programs as means of therapy; some experts say sessions, which allow children to work through fears in group setting, are more effective than standard therapy.
lead_paragraph: The anxiety disorder affects roughly one in 140 children. Researchers are taking a different tack in treating it: intensive immersion programs.

headline.main: Coaxing Children With Selective Mutism to Find Their Voices
headline.print_headline: Scared Into Silence, Little Voices Learn to Speak
